Star of the Match: Gosens highlights
Germany

• After going two EURO finals matches without scoring – both against France – Germany struck four goals in a group game at the tournament for the first time as Joachim Löw's side came from behind to beat Fernando Santos's Portugal 4-2 in Munich on Matchday 2. They had also won by that scoreline in the quarter-finals of UEFA EURO 2012 against a Greece side led by the same coach.

• The defeat by France on Matchday 1 was Germany's third in four tournament matches having lost two of their three games at the 2018 World Cup – both of those also without scoring. It was the second successive major finals in which Germany had lost their opening match and the first time they had done so at the UEFA European Championship. In Russia three years ago they lost their first game (vs Mexico) and won the second (vs Sweden) but then also lost their third (vs South Korea) to go out at the group stage.

• Germany's two pre-UEFA EURO 2020 friendlies brought a 1-1 draw with Denmark in Innsbruck and a 7-1 romp against Latvia in Düsseldorf in which there were seven different goalscorers the first of them Robin Gosens opening his account for the Mannschaft. The Atalanta player was also on target against Portugal in which he won the Star of the Match award.
Star of the Match: Gosens on Germany win

• Those two warm-up games were notable for the return of erstwhile stalwarts Mats Hummels and Thomas Müller neither of whom had played for Germany since November 2018. Christian Günter had an even longer wait for a return to national colours his second cap as a substitute in the draw against Denmark coming seven years after his first while Kevin Volland's appearance in Innsbruck was his first since November 2016.

• The game against Latvia was also a significant one for goalkeeper and captain Manuel Neuer as it was his 100th international appearance for Germany making him the third centurion in the UEFA EURO 2020 squad alongside Müller and Toni Kroos (now both 104 caps) and the first German goalkeeper ever to reach that landmark.

• Twelve players survived that early exit from the 2018 World Cup to retain their places in Joachim Löw's selection this time around though only eight remain from UEFA EURO 2016 – Neuer Hummels Müller Kroos Joshua Kimmich and non-World Cup participants Bernd Leno Emre Can and Leroy Sané.
Löw: 'We have winning spirit'

• Until Kai Havertz scored Germany's third goal against Portugal no player in Löw's UEFA EURO 2020 squad had ever found the net at the EURO finals. Müller has now competed in 13 final tournament matches without a goal Kroos in 12 and Hummels – an own goal scorer against France – in 11. Müller who in contrast has scored ten World Cup final tournament goals even missed his penalty in the 2016 quarter-final shoot-out against Italy.

• Eight members of Bayern München's 2020/21 Bundesliga-winning side have been selected for this squad – Neuer Kimmich Sané Müller Serge Gnabry Leon Goretzka Niklas Süle and Jamal Musiala the youngest player in the party at 18.

• Other 2020/21 trophy winners in the squad are Dortmund pair Hummels and Can who won the DFB-Pokal Manchester City's Premier League champion İlkay Gündoğan and UEFA Champions League winners Antonio Rüdiger Timo Werner and final goalscorer Havertz of Chelsea.

• There were 21 members of Löw's EURO squad in UEFA Champions League action during the 2020/21 season plus Leno in the UEFA Europa League with only Freiburg's Günter Monaco's Volland Eintracht Frankfurt's Kevin Trapp and Leeds United's Robin Koch not involved in continental club competition.
Star of the Match: Kleinheisler highlights
Hungary

• Attila Fiola's goal against France was only his second for Hungary in 37 internationals his first having come on his 34th appearance in a 4-1 World Cup qualifying win against San Marino earlier this year.

• Hungary's defeat by Portugal on Matchday 1 ended the team's long unbeaten run that had stretched to 11 matches when they defeated Cyprus 1-0 and drew 0-0 with the Republic of Ireland in their two pre-UEFA EURO 2020 friendlies both played at the Ferenc Szusza Stadion in Budapest. Marco Rossi's side remain undefeated outside the Hungarian capital however in six matches winning five since their final UEFA EURO 2020 group qualifier a 0-2 defeat to Wales in Cardiff.

• András Schäfer's first international goal settled the contest against Cyprus a game in which János Hahn and Bendegúz Bolla both made their Hungary debuts. Those two players were again involved against Ireland when another player Szabolcs Schön earned his first cap and recalled goalkeeper Ádám Bogdán came off the bench to make his first international appearance for over five years.

• Hahn was the top scorer in the 2020/21 Hungarian top flight with 22 goals for Paks the two players just behind him – Fehérvár's Nemanja Nikolić (15) and Honvéd's Dániel Gazdag (13) – having also both made the UEFA EURO 2020 squad along with five members of the title-winning Ferencváros side – Dénes Dibusz Gergő Lovrencsics Dávid Sigér Endre Botka and Bogdán.
Star of the Match: Kleinheisler reaction to Hungary point
• Ádám Lang was also a league champion in 2020/21 winning the Cypriot league with Omonoia for whom he also started all six group games in the UEFA Europa League.

• Ádám Szalai was the only player in Marco Rossi's squad to have scored at a major tournament until Fiola struck against France. Hungary captain Szalai who was substituted in the first half against the world champions found the net against Austria at UEFA EURO 2016 and is one of nine Hungarian survivors from that event along with Lang Lovrencsics Nikolić Fiola László Kleinheisler Ádám Nagy and unused goalkeepers Dibusz and Péter Gulácsi.

• Skipper Szalai is also the only player in the Hungary squad with more than 50 caps and ten international goals to his name boasting respective tallies of 72 and 23. Nagy made his 50th appearance in the draw against France.

• Hungary's EURO play-off match-winner Dominik Szoboszlai was ruled out of the final tournament with a groin injury that has sidelined him since he joined Leipzig from Salzburg at the turn of the year.",https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiQmh0dHBzOi8vdGhlYXRobGV0aWMuY29tLzIyOTI1NzUvMjAyMS8wMS8wMi9wcmVtaWVyLWxlYWd1ZS13YXJtLXVwL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen,How Premier League teams warm up: Klopp staring passes between mates and rondos,"It’s fair to say Andrea Pirlo was not a fan of the warm-up saying in his autobiography: “I hate it with every fibre of my being. It actually disgusts me.”
Yet it plays a vital part in teams’ preparations — arguably even more so during a congested season in which fans remain largely absent from stadiums.

Some managers leave things to their assistant and fitness coaches while others take part themselves watch avidly or like Jurgen Klopp use the time to observe the opposition. Here The Athletic looks at how each Premier League side warms up and analyses what it says about that particular team…
Arsenal
Goalkeepers Bernd Leno and Runar Alex Runarsson are usually first out facing shots from goalkeeper coach Inaki Cana.

The rest of the squad emerge 40 minutes before kick-off splitting into pairs to share passes across the width of the pitch. Here we usually see friends pair off with each other: Hector Bellerin and Dani Ceballos tend to work together for instance.
Advertisement

After a few minutes the squad split between starters and substitutes (goalkeepers excluded). The starters begin their fitness drills with Shad Forsythe as the benched players whose drilled were completed before the starters work with Sam Wilson.

Starters then break off into three groups passing between themselves before a larger more intense group rondo. There are three neutral players (grey bibs) four in green bibs and another four without bibs and Kieran Tierney tends to be the only player in short sleeves in the winter months.

Some 25 minutes before kick-off the starters split into two groups. A defensive group of four and an attacking six. This isn’t indicative of how they’ll line up however as there have been multiple occasions when one of the two wing-backs (usually left-sided) is included in the attacking six working on combinations to get into the box.

After five minutes the attacking group head over to the corner of the pitch to do their shooting drills (a one-two with a coach before shooting at goal). Centre-backs and full-backs can often be seen pinging the ball between each other cross-field.
Then come the quick sprints before the starters disappear down the tunnel shortly followed by the substitutes who aim speculative efforts at goal with 15 minutes until kick-off.
Art de Roche
Arsenal players stretching ahead of their 1-0 win at Brighton in December (Photo: Neil Hall/Pool/Getty Images)
Aston Villa

Villa’s warm-up drills have varied since football has been largely played behind closed doors. There’s a distinct lack of fancy flicks sublime take-ons and those seemingly-casual volleyed passes between two players that bring a twinkle to the eyes of young supporters watching on from the sidelines.

Some things haven’t changed though: boss Dean Smith watches on from the tunnel to check out the opposition during shooting practice Tyrone Mings always asks assistant manager John Terry to throw up some balls that he can head away just before he starts and Jack Grealish tends to sprint off the pitch first after completing his warm-up. Make of that what you will.
Advertisement
In short though Villa tend to follow a basic schedule. The goalkeepers emerge first usually 45 minutes before kick-off. Their warm-up consists of basic catching drills followed by some shot-stopping.
The outfield players follow five minutes later. Routine running drills get the process started and then it’s on to a few group stretches.

A five-a-side one-touch game is then set up for the starting players and is overseen by the assistant coaches Craig Shakespeare Terry and Richard O’Kelly. In the closing period O’Kelly takes the attacking players into one of the goals to start a shooting practice session while Terry gives a few words of encouragement to the defenders.

To finish there’s always a group huddle. Terry and Shakespeare often offer up some motivational messages during a brief 30-second chat which are typically always positive and about the team rather than anything tactical.
Gregg Evans
Brighton
If only Brighton had two nets to aim at when it counts.

A temporary net next to the proper one is used during their warm-up routine. Attackers and midfielders exchange passes with Graham Potter’s assistant Billy Reid or coach Bruno Saltor before trying to fire past one of the goalkeepers.
Dan Burn and Brighton team-mates warming up ahead of their 0-0 draw against Burnley in November (Photo: Richard Heathcote/Getty Images)
Brighton might seem reluctant to shoot when the real action begins but they are always well prepared beforehand.
The goalkeepers work as much with their feet as their hands with Ben Roberts. The goalkeeping coach plays the role of an opposing attacker in passing drills closing them down in the penalty box.
In another area of the pitch defenders work in pairs on short and long-range passing and headers.
The players are brought back together as one group for a final burst of quick steps and short-distance sprints before heading back to the dressing room.
Unfortunately that other net disappears with them.
Andy Naylor
Burnley
The Burnley warm-up has slightly changed in the last few weeks since the final game before the November international break.

It starts with some loosening up in groups of four beginning with some light running and stretching before moving on to ball work with a short passing drill which then progresses into two rondos. As you would expect with Burnley the tempo is high.
Advertisement

Previously the starting XI would then be involved in a keep-ball session with the substitutes moving to the corner of the pitch to take part in another rondo drill. The change from Dyche and his coaching staff means that now all outfield players are involved in the keep-ball session separated into two teams with the central midfielders operating on whichever team has the ball. Led by first-team coach Tony Loughlan it is loud it is intense. It is Burnley and all of their values.

There is another running exercise which is short sharp and intense before the defensive players and attacking players split off into two different drills. The attacking players will go through their attacking patterns with Ian Woan instructing while the defensive four work with Loughlan defending a range of passes — low high long and short — played by the substitutes with plenty of communication.
The warm-up is finished up with your typical shooting drill while the defenders knock long passes to each other before a final intense sprint.
Andy Jones
Ashley Barnes warming up ahead of facing Chelsea this season (Photo: Oli Scarff/Pool/Getty Images)
Chelsea

Approximately an hour before the start of a home game at Stamford Bridge the reserve goalkeepers will be first out onto the pitch accompanied by goalkeeping coach Hilario. After some light stretches they get to work in a temporary goal positioned near the touchline going through exercises designed to test their reactions to low saves and comfort level with the ball at their feet.
Edouard Mendy joins them around 15 minutes later setting his towel and bottle down by the real goal before quickly getting involved in a one-touch passing drill with the other two led by Hilario.

Chelsea’s outfield players then make their entrance and are swiftly divided into two groups: the starters and the substitutes. It’s quite free-form for the first few minutes with some players kicking around one of the many loose balls on the pitch and others doing light stretches but the starters are soon whisked off to one side by a fitness coach. They gather in a circle slip black elasticated bands around their knees and do squats then lower them to their ankles and repeatedly move their feet apart.
Advertisement

Next up it’s short shuttle runs featuring sidesteps leg and knee raises as well as jumps and miming headers. Then they re-form the circle bending over with legs apart raising up and swinging arms swinging legs shifting from one knee to the other and hopping on one leg. After another round of jumps and mimed headers they finish with another round of shuttle sprints.

The substitutes are then brought over separately to go through the same routine while the starters begin a one-touch pass-and-move drill with low and high passes followed by a rondo with a difference: one teammate is positioned in the middle of the circle between the bib-wearing chasers and the task is to bounce passes off him without being dispossessed.
Chelsea save the best exercise for last: a shooting drill where every player initiates a one-two and then tries to beat the goalkeeper with a first-time finish – with highly varied results.
Liam Twomey
Crystal Palace
Palace’s warm-up suits a team that plays on the counter-attack and needs to clear its lines both short and long likely to be under pressure.

First out are the goalkeepers who form a triangle with goalkeeping coach Dean Kiely to play short passes to each other before he then takes shots at them incrementally increasing the distance as he goes along and finally testing them with crosses and corners.

The starting XI arrive on the pitch to some freestyle jogging and passing generally playing with the ball and then they join the head of sports science Scott Guyett to jog across the pitch in a horizontal line and back again..
Substitutes participate in a game of piggy in the middle with one player trying to intercept passes in a small circle and then they stretch.

The starters then do some sprints various stretches and then go over to the Lower Holmesdale Stand at Selhurst Park to do shuttle runs. They take part in a pass-and-move routine with first-team coach Dave Reddington observing. Pass control and replace in a clockwise movement who they pass it to. Afterwards they play a small-sided game trying to keep the ball. The forwards participate in a shooting drill in which they pass to Reddington who lays it off for them to take one touch and shoot at Vicente Guaita.
Advertisement

The midfielders pass the ball between themselves over a medium distance while the defenders are with Guyett who throws the ball down hard and bounces it just in front of them prioritising close control before throwing it up in the air for them to head back to him. Then they play long balls to each other pass short then play it long.
In the final act they do a small series of shuttle runs in front of the Lower Holmesdale before heading inside 15 minutes before kick-off.
Matt Woosnam
Everton
The players come out and dribble balls around individually while the goalkeepers work separately with Alan Kelly starting with long-range kicking in opposite halves of the pitch.

There are 11 cones set out for the starting XI who do a series of short shuttle runs stretches and short sprints with Francesco Mauri the fitness coach. Then two small rondos with a difference: the player in the middle takes and distributes the ball then it is passed around the circle. Then two teams do another rondo with the aim of keeping and winning back the ball. The substitutes warm up separately.

After there is shooting for the midfielders and attackers while the central defenders practice heading with assistant manager Duncan Ferguson then passing. Some players opt to work individually at this point.
As has been the way since Carlo Ancelotti arrived the squad finish with some shuttle runs one against one and then head for the tunnel.
Patrick Boyland
Fulham
Whether home or away Scott Parker always finds a way to watch his troops before battle.

Away from home this will be anywhere with a decent view. At Leicester for instance he watched on from the mouth of the tunnel. At Craven Cottage though the Fulham head coach will sit flanked sometimes by an analyst on the balcony of the Cottage itself watching on as his coaching staff put his starters through their paces.
Parker always watches his side warm up (Photo: Richard Heathcote/Getty Images)

The goalkeepers work together alongside coach Rob Burch moving through shot-stopping wide deliveries and distribution drills. The substitutes will normally do rondos in their own circle while those who are set to start outfield begin with dynamic movements and stretches. They split between two lines before forming a circle and undertaking their static stretches — led by head of performance Alastair Harris.
Advertisement

There is opportunity for important instructions to be delivered at this point with assistant Matt Wells one to convey key information. These drills are then concluded with sprints that increase in tempo. From there they split into pairs under the watch of assistants Wells and Stuart Gray getting a feel of the ball for the first time with one and two-touch passing.

The group then moves into more technical preparation. A square normally around 15 metres by 15 metres is laid out for retention-based drills (keep-ball). The first drill for example sees the team split into three colours
column2: comprised of four four and three players. A four vs four takes place in the middle and the other three split with one at each end and one free within the square. Frequently the split pair will be the central defenders but this rotates.

column1: After different variations the starting XI break off with the back-four working together alongside Gray dealing with aerial balls and other direct passes aiming to maintain their line. The forwards go for shooting practice while the midfielders work on a range of passing short and long. The defenders’ drill concludes with some longer passing between them.
After that it’s back to the dressing room and the last few words from Parker before showtime.
Peter Rutzler
Leeds United

Leeds’ outfield players warm up about 40 minutes before kick-off starting with players pairing off and passing back and forward to each other over 10 to 20 yards for five minutes. This is very relaxed
column2: looseners more than anything. The goalkeepers are always out 15-20 minutes earlier.

column1: The 16 outfield players then go into a group with fitness coach Benoit Delaval. He hands out orange bibs to half of the players and they then do some short shuttle runs on one touchline with arm rotations and leg muscle stretches as they go. They then get in a huddle for a few words of encouragement.
Advertisement

After that most of the substitutes peel off and the remaining group intensifies their shuttle runs. A quick drink next. After that they form four lines (two facing each other 30 yards apart). The lines pass balls back and forward between each other — one touch and then pass never two touches.

Next they move into a square of cones and do keep-ball with the bibs against non-bibs. There’s one floating player (in a green bid as opposed to orange) who helps whichever group is in possession. After about five mins they move onto shots against the second-choice keeper.
Lastly the 10 outfield starters move to the byline and do short sharp bursts of running over five to 10 yards. That’s them done 15 minutes before kick-off.
Phil Hay
Leicester City

This hasn’t altered much during Brendan Rodgers’ time as manager. It starts an hour before kick-off when Kasper Schmeichel and the other goalkeepers come out and begin by practising their distribution before some close-range saving drills.

The rest of the players usually come out 40 minutes before kick-off and split into three groups. They begin with small-sided passing drills before the starting XI are involved in more dynamic warm-up exercises under the guidance of the club’s fitness and conditioning coach Matt Reeves.
(Photo: Glyn Kirk/Pool/Getty Images)

The substitutes continue with keepy-up drills in a circle while goalkeeping coach Mike Stowell continues to work with Schmeichel and substitute goalkeeper Danny Ward plus third choice keeper Eldin Jakupovic firing balls into them out of his hands from the penalty spot.

Reeves then moves to work with the substitutes utilising similar dynamic stretching exercises. The players are always moving. The starters return to short close-range ball work before switching to a short-sided game in a square where one team hunts the ball in the middle and the other side must protect it.
Advertisement

Coach Kolo Toure will then work with the back five especially the back three who work on their shape practising dropping as a unit as they take it in turns to attack high balls and balls bounced into them while the attacking players will join the keepers for shooting drills.
Rob Tanner
Liverpool

Jurgen Klopp is standing in the centre circle at Anfield his arms folded across his chest as he stares intently at the opposition warming up. Behind him coaches Pep Lijnders and Vitor Matos watch on as their players divide themselves into pairs and knock 10-to-15-yard passes to each other across the turf.
It’s the first drill in a 22-minute warm-up for the outfield players who emerge from the tunnel some seven minutes after John Achterberg has started putting the goalkeepers through their paces.

After five minutes head of fitness and conditioning Andreas Kornmayer calls the 10 outfield starters into a circle in the centre of the pitch while the substitutes embark on a series of rondos together in front of the Main Stand. The “drill sergeant” as he’s affectionately known by Klopp oversees a range of stretches before again they are paired off for some short sharp running exercises.

Then Lijnders steps in handing out white and yellow bibs as they head towards the Kenny Dalglish Stand. A small pitch is already marked out using cones. It’s five vs five. The two centre-backs stand at each end wearing yellow while in front of them it’s the four in white against the four in the training jackets. It’s one touch and it’s frenetic as Lijnders barks orders.
It’s all about ensuring Liverpool are ready to perform with the kind of tempo and intensity Klopp demands.

For most the final five minutes of the warm-up means shooting practice. However the two centre-backs are exempt as they take it in turns to throw balls into the air for the other to head before spreading out to exchange 40-yard cross-field passes.
Advertisement

There are three elements to the shooting drill for midfielders and attackers which involves the full-backs darting down the wing. There’s a cross from the left and then one from the right to dispatch. Thirdly there’s a lay-off from a team-mate close to the edge of the penalty box and you turn before hammering goalwards.
The players stop for a brief drink before Kornmayer brings them together again in front of the Main Stand. There are a series of jumps and sprints in twos before they dart off down the tunnel.
James Pearce
Manchester City

Pep Guardiola’s two assistants Rodolfo Borrell and Juanma Lillo make an interesting double act because the former is a big bear of a man and the latter is pretty diminutive. They set the drills up on the far side of the pitch at the Etihad (which happens to be furthest from where the media are) and the players soon follow them out some of them bursting out of the tunnel with a ball at their feet. Riyad Mahrez is usually among the very first out.
For a few minutes they do their own thing but then partner off into twos to pass between them and these tend to be quite telling partnerships: Ferran Torres and Eric Garcia the two young Spaniards
column2: Mahrez and Mendy the French speakers
column3: Jesus and Cancelo two Portuguese speakers and then Rodri and Gundogan who are very important at the heart of the City midfield.

column1: Borrell hands out bibs of different colours and then it’s the usual warm-up routine for the starters led by Lorenzo Buenaventura Guardiola’s trusted fitness coach. They’re seen squatting down low to warm up the quads and hamstrings shuttling from side to side swaying their arms about lifting their legs over imaginary gates.
Bernardo Silva and Kevin De Bruyne prepare to face Southampton in December (Photo: Paul Childs/Pool/AFP via Getty Images)

The subs do this too with lesser intensity on the near side of the pitch. Their warm-up is a lot more laidback and indeed half the subs don’t always come out for a few minutes and then their ball work will mostly be keeping the ball up in the air in a little circle. Whoever loses gets their ear flicked.
Advertisement

The starting XI then break off into little groups of three or four. They pass it around between themselves quite casually and then it turns into a four-vs-one rondo not especially intense. They then all return to the far side for a bigger rondo with eight around the outside and two in the middle.

The goalkeepers have been working on crosses and kicking but then everybody is back to the near side of the pitch for a shooting drill where the players line up behind each other pass it into feet get it back and shoot. Mikel Arteta used to lay the ball off but it rotates around some of the players now with Phil Foden doing it quite often. Zack Steffen goes in goal while Ederson continues working on his kicking and the other subs keep the ball in the air again.

The starters do little short bursts of sprinting along the near touchline and then they’re off down the tunnel again. Some of the subs depending on who they are can stay out for a little longer playing around. On one occasion Foden stayed out the longest dribbling a ball all the way up to the goal and booting it in long after everyone else had gone in.

That tells us a lot about Foden and his desire to kick a ball around no matter what. As for the team there’s a lot of focus on short sharp passes although this can change depending on the type of game: against Newcastle away at the end of last season the centre-backs worked on heading the ball which was partly to get them acclimatised to tracking the ball against a backdrop of empty black and white seats.
With City it can be a case of different warm-ups for different needs but the focus on passing predictably is always there.
Sam Lee
Manchester United
As discussed here United do a lot of rondos during their warm-up.

The United warm-ups in Louis Van Gaal’s era were characterised by attacking outfield players lining up in formation and going through a series of near-identical passing moves that finished with the winger or full-back squaring and the forward putting the ball into an empty net. Frequently when opponents were involved however things didn’t flow quite so smoothly.
Advertisement

Ryan Giggs liked to conserve energy too during his 24-year career. In our interview in May Giggs told how he realised his approach differed to Louis van Gaal’s when he became assistant to the Dutchman at United. “Louis used to always say ‘What was the warm-up like?’” explained Giggs. Often the players were “poor” and Van Gaal would be aghast. But Giggs added: “As a player I used to simply warm up for the game so I would take it easy. I would have been a nightmare under Louis I didn’t want to peak in the warm-up.”

For last season’s visit to Old Trafford by Liverpool it was possible to detect Ole Gunnar Solskjaer had selected a surprise back three as Harry Maguire Victor Lindelof and Axel Tuanzebe warmed up together. Tuanzebe then suffered an injury and jogged down the tunnel early with Marcos Rojo stepping up from the reserve group.
Manchester United players getting in the zone at Bramall Lane (Photo: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images)

Kieran McKenna is the coach who leads this section of the warm-up at United tossing the ball high for aerial clearances or firing it along the ground to sharpen control. For other positions groups of two or four might break out for passing drills. Each player has a different way of striking the ball — Bruno Fernandes tends to apply topspin — so a reminder of that before kick-off is somewhat useful.

Midfielders and strikers will inevitably finish the pre-match routine with some shots from the edge of the box at the reserve goalkeeper. The No 1 catches crosses and passes out from his box to various distances. There are of course stretches and running sequences. The simple requirement is to get blood circulating and muscles flexed.
Laurie Whitwell
Sheffield United
United’s warm-ups have been pretty uniform under Chris Wilder with one big exception at West Bromwich Albion this season.

First-team coach Matt Prestridge will usually lead the players through their stretching exercises as Alan Knill wanders around passing on advice and words of encouragement but Wilder got much more involved at The Hawthorns. He was there throughout either watching from a distance during the exercises or cajoling his players in the shuttle runs. This increased hands-on approach extended to lobbing the ball to his strikers during shooting practice.
Wilder employed an unusually hands-on approach at West Brom (Photo: Andrew Boyers/Pool/Getty Images)

It didn’t work United having 22 efforts and an expected goals (xG) of 3.12 but still failed to find the net in a 1-0 defeat. Since then United have returned to the norm with Knill and Prestridge overseeing things on the pitch and Wilder taking a back seat.

United’s routine starts with stretching then the squad breaks so the 11 starting take part in small-sided game where priority is keeping the ball. As this happens the subs work together on passing. Then the strikers break away for shooting drills as the rest work on passing skills in another part of the pitch before everyone returns to the dressing room about 10-15 minutes before kick-off.
Richard Sutcliffe
Newcastle
What must Newcastle United improve most?
Many would argue their passing and so it is encouraging to see that a large section of their warm-up is dedicated to the art — or at least it was ahead of the goalless draw with Liverpool.
Their match preparations begin with Jamie Harley the club’s head of sports science leading dynamic stretches. Two lines of cones are placed on the ground and players copy his techniques.
Advertisement

Next the players are split into two teams half with yellow bibs and half without for a passing drill overseen by Stephen Clemence and Steve Agnew the first-team coaches. Both sides must simultaneously attempt one-touch passes to navigate their way up the small cordoned area. This then evolves into a two-touch passing game where two “neutral” players with orange bibs are placed at either end. Rather than goalkeepers they are additional team-mates for both sides with the aim to keep possession rather than score.

Finally the players split off by position with Matt Ritchie practising receiving possession and crossing with Agnew while Clemence leads the majority of the rest of the players in a shooting drill. The coach receives a pass from an attacker just outside the area and lays it back for them to shoot at a goalkeeper.
Whatever the preparations they were successful against Liverpool — but passing remains a “work in progress” as Steve Bruce might say.
Chris Waugh
Southampton
Southampton’s pre-match warm-up doesn’t particularly reflect the intensity with which the team play.

Alek Gross the club’s head of sports science and first-team fitness coach leads the squad through several exercises although the first few minutes sees the players pass the ball around between themselves. Gross will then without fail guide the team through multiple exercises between a set of cones. These include movements such as high knees and are designed to loosen the muscles.
Next on the agenda is stretching.
The first-team fitness coach gathers the squad into a large circle before the players stretch in unison. Once this is over they head back to the cones and do several sprints.

This though is where Gross’ involvement ends and Ralph Hasenhuttl’s management team take over. Hasenhuttl who often remains inside during the warm-up leaves Dave Watson Kelvin Davis and Craig Fleming in charge. Fellow assistant Richard Kitzbichler observes proceedings from the technical area.
Advertisement
The squad are split into three teams and play a small-sided passing game together and then finish the warm-up with a shooting drill.
Tellingly though defenders Jan Bednarek and Jannik Vestergaard don’t take shots on goal. Instead they go to the other side of the pitch and practice headers with each other.
Dan Sheldon
Tottenham Hotspur

During a Tottenham warm-up there tends to be one player that your eyes are instinctively drawn to. Tanguy Ndombele can normally be found practising his tricks and flicks whenever there is an idle moment. It is as mesmerising to watch as the drops of the shoulder and perfectly-weighted passes he produces in matches.
(Photo: Tottenham Hotspur FC via Getty Images)

Generally though the Tottenham warm-ups are pretty businesslike affairs. After going through dynamic stretches the players join together for a rondo but instead of standing around in a circle the players are constantly moving as they receive the ball and after they’ve passed it.

The group will then split with Ledley King looking after the defenders and giving them exercises like lobbing balls up in the air for them to head. Then they will do a series of quick repetitions of volleying the ball back to him before he will test their acceleration by rolling balls in front of them to run and sprint onto.

The attackers meanwhile will do exercises like practising their shooting — passing receiving a lay-off passing again and then smashing a shot normally past the goalkeeper. The other keeper will be practising getting up and down quickly as the goalkeeping coach Nuno Santos throws balls in different directions for him to save.
After more stretching and a few sprints the players return to the dressing room for their final instructions. Then it’s game time.
Charlie Eccleshare
West Brom
The goalkeepers emerge ahead of the rest of the squad and started with some long-range kicking before moving on to claiming crosses and finally some close-up shot-stopping.

The outfield players split into two groups with the 10 starters doing a more intensive warm-up than those on the bench. The majority of the drill is a high-tempo keep-ball session when most of the hard work is done by the two players charged with winning the ball back.

Under new boss Sam Allardyce that lasts for around 10 minutes and seems a little more intense than it had been under Slaven Bilic. Sammy Lee leads it and gees up individual players whereas Bilic’s coaches generally observed while the fitness coaches led the drills.
(Photo: David Rogers/Getty Images)

The starting players then split into two groups with Lee leading the back four in a final few minutes on shape and positioning while the remaining six do shooting practice. The subs didn’t see the ball and did some much less intensive stretching which seemed to be just designed to stay loose.

Against Leeds United there was a moment of drama in the warm-up when Kieran Gibbs was hit by a ball and ruled out of the game with Lee Peltier moved from the subs to the starters having missed most of the warm-up session.
Steve Madeley
West Ham
When the players have inspected the pitch and returned to the dressing room quite often it is Darren Randolph David Martin and Lukasz Fabianski who are out first for the warm-up.

Goalkeeping coach Xavi Valero runs a number of drills noticeably crossing the ball into the box where Fabianski Randolph and Martin will leap into the air to catch it. Before the session finishes the players will attempt shots against the second and third-choice goalkeepers.
Advertisement

The starting XI will jog onto the field and begin to do stretches jumping on the spot and doing pass and movement drills. Shortly after the substitutes will appear and it is very common for them to do passing drills with different players taking turns being in the middle. Kevin Nolan the first-team coach will often join in while David Moyes tends to watch the opposition team during their warm-up.
Roshane Thomas
Wolves
For a team that prides itself on an enviable injury record it’s no surprise that loosening up muscles plays a key part of Wolves’ warm-up.

The fact Wolves currently have four players out injured is deemed a crisis by their incredibly high standards (they only suffered five short-term injuries during the whole of 2018-19 for example) shows how seriously they take injury prevention.

A 30-minute warm-up against Aston Villa starts with some light jogging overseen by fitness and sport science gurus Antonio Dias and Joao Lapa. It’s a sedentary start which continues when the players then stand 20 yards apart in pairs passing the ball to each other stopping occasionally to stretch their calves under instruction.
The passing drill then evolves into players turning on the spot shadowed by Dias or Lapa who grapple with them before the player breaks free and passes the ball on.
Next there are some kneeling lunges a 50-yard long passing routine and then a running drill bleep-test style sprinting 20 yards before turning back again.

There’s a quick break as first-team sports rehabilitator Danny Fishwick dishes out energy drinks before the intensity is lifted by some high impact running knees up over a ladder laid out on the side on the pitch.
Quick short sprints in pairs is followed by lunging over hurdles to stretch the inside of their legs then keepy-ups 10 yards apart.
Advertisement

Finally it’s on to some football in the form of crossing and shooting practice. The ball is played to both sides of the penalty area where wing-backs Nelson Semedo or Marcal cross low into the box for either Pedro Neto Daniel Podence Adama Traore Leander Dendoncker Fabio Silva or Joao Moutinho to run onto and shoot.

The warm-up concludes with 20-yard shots versus John Ruddy in goal. A player takes a pass with their back to goal spins and shoots. Podence rolls one in off the post Neto lashes one in the corner and Ruddy makes a sprawling save from Moutinho before the players head down the tunnel.
Tim Spiers

(Top photo: Clive Rose/Pool/AFP via Getty Images)",https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiiQFodHRwczovL3d3dy51ZWZhLmNvbS91ZWZhZXVyby9oaXN0b3J5L25ld3MvMDI1Zi0wZmM4MWVlZmZiMDYtYzY4YWYwMTM5ZWE1LTEwMDAtLXBvcnR1Z2FsLXZzLWZyYW5jZS11ZWZhLWV1cm8tMjAyMC1tYXRjaC1iYWNrZ3JvdW5kLWZhY3RzL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen,Portugal vs France: UEFA EURO 2020 match background facts and stats,"There is a repeat of the UEFA EURO 2016 final on Matchday 3 in Budapest as holders Portugal meet the team they beat to the title in the last tournament France in the concluding round of Group F games.
• Portugal picked up their first major silverware on French soil thanks to Éder's extra-time winner at the Stade de France on 10 July 2016 denying France a second home EURO title and a third overall.

• Didier Deschamps' France gained a measure of revenge by ending Portugal's defence of the UEFA Nations League taking four points off Fernando Santos's side in autumn 2020 to qualify for the Finals ahead of their opponents.

• France are top of Group F on four points one above Portugal and Germany although they were held 1-1 by Hungary in Budapest on Matchday 2 having opened with a 1-0 defeat of Germany in Munich. Portugal beat Hungary 3-0 in their opening game in Budapest but were then beaten 4-2 by Germany in Munich.
• France are through and will finish first if they win or if they draw and Germany do not beat Hungary. If France lose and Hungary win second place will be decided on overall goal difference.
• Portugal will go through if they avoid defeat. They will finish first if they win and Germany do not. Portugal will finish fourth if they lose and Germany also lose.
Previous meetings
• Going into the final of UEFA EURO 2016 France had won ten successive matches between the sides and have still triumphed in 19 of the nations' 27 meetings (D2 L6).
EURO 2016 final highlights: Portugal 1-0 France

• Despite losing talisman and captain Cristiano Ronaldo to injury with only 25 minutes played in that final Fernando Santos's Portugal claimed the trophy thanks to a 109th-minute strike from substitute Éder – who had spent the second half of the 2015/16 season playing in France for LOSC Lille and whose goal was his only competitive strike for his country.

• That ended a French winning streak against Portugal that had stretched back over 40 years to a 2-0 friendly success for Portugal at the Parc des Princes in April 1975 Nené and Marinho scoring the goals.

• That long sequence of France wins against Portugal included victories in the semi-finals at the UEFA European Championship in 1984 (3-2) and 2000 (2-1) – when current coach Didier Deschamps was Les Bleus' captain – in addition to a 1-0 victory at the same stage of the 2006 FIFA World Cup. Zinédine Zidane converted penalty winners in each of the last two games.
EURO 2000 masterclass: Zidane v Portugal
• France had therefore won all three of their competitive matches against Portugal before the UEFA EURO 2016 final.
• The last friendly between the sides ended in a 1-0 France win in Lisbon in September 2015 Mathieu Valbuena scoring the only goal.
• Karim Benzema scored past Rui Patrício in France's 2-1 friendly win against Portugal at the Stade de France on 11 October 2014.

• After a goalless UEFA Nations League draw at the Stade de France on 11 October 2020 France's N'Golo Kanté scored the only goal after 53 minutes at Lisbon's Estádio do Sport Lisboa e Benfica on 14 November to secure first place in Group A3 and a place in this autumn's final tournament.
EURO facts: Portugal
• A 2-0 semi-final win against Wales was Portugal's only victory inside 90 minutes at UEFA EURO 2016
column2: before Matchday 1 it was the only one of their previous eight EURO finals matches that was not all square after 90 minutes.

column1: • At UEFA EURO 2016 Santos's side had finished third in Group F behind Hungary and Iceland having drawn all three games before beating Croatia 1-0 after extra time in the round of 16 and Poland 5-3 on penalties after their quarter-final had finished 1-1.
Watch great Portugal goals
• Santos went on to guide Portugal to victory in the inaugural UEFA Nations League in 2019 the hosts beating Switzerland 3-1 in the semi-finals before a 1-0 final defeat of the Netherlands.

• Portugal were Group B runners-up in UEFA EURO 2020 qualifying finishing three points behind Ukraine and three ahead of Serbia. Portugal drew their first two games both at home against Ukraine (0-0) and Serbia (1-1) but won five of the next six (L1).
• The 4-2 defeat in Germany on Matchday 2 in a game Portugal had led 1-0 was only their second defeat in 24 EURO matches (W16 D6) the other a 2-1 qualifying reverse in Ukraine on 14 October 2019.
• Cristiano Ronaldo scored 11 qualifying goals one behind top scorer Harry Kane of England and has three at these finals.

• Ronaldo has made the most appearance in EURO final tournaments (23). The competition's top scorer overall on 43 goals he is also the top marksman in final tournaments on 12 his double against Hungary on Matchday 1 taking him clear of Michel Platini with whom he had shared the record on nine.
Portugal vs France: EURO meetings
• Portugal are competing at their seventh consecutive EURO and their eighth in total.

• An André Silva goal gave Portugal victory in a 2018 World Cup qualifier against Hungary at Budapest's Ferencváros Stadion on 3 September 2017. The Matchday 1 defeat of Hungary at these finals made their record in the country and city played four won four
column2: Pepe scored the only goal in another World Cup qualifying win in September 2009 this time at the Ferenc Puskás Stadium with Ronaldo captaining the side in both games.

column1: • This is Portugal's second game at the Puskás Aréna having beaten Hungary there on Matchday 1.
EURO facts: France
• The final defeat by Portugal in 2016 denied France the chance to claim their third EURO title following their triumphs of 1984 and 2000.

• In 2016 Deschamps' team had finished first in their group ahead of Switzerland Albania and Romania before beating the Republic of Ireland 2-1 – their first EURO knockout win since 2000 – in the round of 16. Iceland (5-2) and Germany (2-0) were then defeated only for Portugal to run out winners in Saint-Denis.
Watch great France goals
• Les Bleus responded to that disappointment by winning their second World Cup in 2018 defeating Croatia 4-2 in the final to add to their title from 20 years earlier.
• Having won consecutive world (1998) and European (2000) titles with France as a player Deschamps can repeat the feat as a coach
column2: France aside only West Germany (1972 EURO 1974 World Cup) and Spain (2008 and 2012 EURO 2010 World Cup) have held both titles at the same time.

column1: • France qualified for the 2020 finals by finishing first in Group H winning eight of their ten qualifiers (D1 L1) to pick up 25 points two more than Turkey.
• The 2-0 loss in Turkey on 8 June 2019 is France's only defeat in 90 minutes in their last 19 EURO games (W14 D4).
1984 highlights: France 3-2 Portugal
• France are appearing at their 13th successive world or European final tournament
column2: they have not missed out since the 1994 World Cup and have reached five finals in that run winning three of them.

column1: • This is France's tenth EURO and their eighth in a row
column2: they last failed to qualify for the 1988 event.

column1: • Like Portugal this is Les Bleus' second game at the Puskás Aréna following their Matchday 2 contest against Hungary.

Top Scorer: All Ronaldo's goals so far
Portugal

• Portugal captain Cristiano Ronaldo's double against Hungary on Matchday 1 maintained his record of scoring in every final tournament in which he has played – 11 in total consisting of five UEFA European Championships four FIFA World Cups one FIFA Confederations Cup and one UEFA Nations League. The 36-year-old's goal against Germany has increased his tally to 24 in 46 tournament appearances.
• Ronaldo's goal against Germany was his 107th for Portugal on his 177th appearance – just two shy of the world record held by Iran's Ali Daei – and his 86th in his 126th competitive international.

• The defeat by Germany in Munich was just the second for Portugal in their last 17 matches the 11 wins over that stretch including a 4-0 success against Israel in Lisbon on 9 June in which Bruno Fernandes scored twice and Ronaldo once. This followed a goalless stalemate against Spain in Madrid five days earlier.

• Pedro Gonçalves the 23-goal breakout star of Sporting CP's 2020/21 Portuguese Liga triumph made his international debut against Spain goalkeeper Rui Silva following suit with a 90-minute outing in the win against Israel. Neither player has appeared yet at UEFA EURO 2020

• Diogo Jota's late consolation strike against Germany was his seventh goal for Portugal all of them in competitive internationals. He joined Ronaldo Pepe Renato Sanches and Matchday 1 marksman Raphaël Guerreiro as the only players in the UEFA EURO 2020 squad to have scored a EURO finals goal for Portugal.

• Portugal possess the three UEFA EURO 2020 participants with most EURO final tournament appearances Pepe and João Moutinho each following record-breaker Ronaldo on the list with 17. Rui Patricio is also in double figures with 14.
Skill of the Day: Cristiano Ronaldo (Portugal)

• Ronaldo was Serie A's top scorer in 2020/21 with 29 goals for Juventus with whom he also won the Coppa Italia. His fellow Portugal forward André Silva also had a prolific season scoring 28 goals in the German Bundesliga for Eintracht Frankfurt.

• Two members of Portugal's UEFA EURO 2020 squad – Rúben Dias and Bernardo Silva – won the English Premier League in 2020/21 with Manchester City while LOSC Lille duo José Fonte and Sanches became champions of France and João Félix won the Spanish Liga with Atlético de Madrid. Joining Ronaldo as domestic cup winners were Borussia Dortmund's Guerreiro and Paris Saint-Germain's Danilo.

• Another Manchester City player João Cancelo was ruled out of the squad on the eve of the tournament through illness and replaced by Diogo Dalot a performer in the recent UEFA European Under-21 Championship in which Portugal finished runners-up to Germany.

• Of the six-home based players in the squad three are from Portuguese champions Sporting with João Palhinha and 18-year-old Nuno Mendes joining Gonçalves for their first involvement in international tournament football.

• Eleven members of Portugal's triumphant UEFA EURO 2016 squad have returned along with coach Fernando Santos to defend the trophy this year – Ronaldo Rui Patrício Fonte Pepe Guerreiro Danilo Moutinho Rafa Silva Sanches William Carvalho and Anthony Lopes.

• All 16 of the players who took the field for Portugal's victory on home soil at the 2019 UEFA Nations League finals have been called up for UEFA EURO 2020 including Gonçalo Guedes who scored the winner in the final against the Netherlands.
Skill of the Day: Paul Pogba (France)
France

• France's 1-1 draw against Hungary brought an end to the team's run of five successive victories – all with clean sheets – that included their opening 1-0 win at UEFA EURO 2020 against Germany in Munich. Les Bleus have now won 17 of their last 22 matches during which they have suffered just one defeat – 0-2 at home to Finland in a Stade de France friendly on 11 November 2020.

• Les Bleus' last competitive loss was in a UEFA EURO 2020 qualifier away to Turkey in June 2019 since when they have won 14 and drawn four of their 18 matches across three competitions. They are unbeaten in nine tournament games (W7 D2) since the final of UEFA EURO 2016.

• The world champions warmed up for UEFA EURO 2020 with two 3-0 home wins defeating Wales in Nice on 2 June with goals from Kylian Mbappé Antoine Griezmann and Ousmane Dembélé and Bulgaria in Saint-Denis six days later a late double from Olivier Giroud – his 45th and 46th international goals – adding to another Griezmann strike.
Antoine Griezmann: EURO 2016 top scorer

• Griezmann has appeared in all of France's last 50 internationals starting every one of the team's 36 competitive matches during that sequence which began in August 2017. Since making his debut for Les Bleus in March 2014 the Barcelona forward has never missed a competitive international starting 51 and coming off the bench in the other three. His 93 caps have brought him 38 goals 24 of them in competitive matches the latest of which earned France a draw against Hungary on Matchday 2.
• France remain unbeaten in the 34 internationals in which Griezmann has scored although the game against Hungary was only the fourth of those games that they have failed to win.

• That goal in the Puskás Arena was Griezmann's seventh at the EURO finals lifting the UEFA EURO 2016 top scorer into joint third place in the all-time list alongside Alan Shearer with only Ronaldo (12) and Michel Platini (nine) ahead of him.

• Didier Deschamps' experienced UEFA EURO 2020 squad includes two centurions in Giroud (109 caps) and captain Hugo Lloris (127). The 26 players collectively have 194 major tournament appearances and 28 goals between them.

• There are 14 of France's 2018 FIFA World Cup winners in the UEFA EURO 2020 squad five of whom were also present on home soil at UEFA EURO 2016 – Lloris Griezmann Giroud Paul Pogba and N'Golo Kanté. Three other players – Moussa Sissoko Kingsley Coman and Lucas Digne – have returned for a second successive EURO having missed out on the World Cup triumph in Russia.

• Karim Benzema has returned to the France fold the friendlies against Wales and Bulgaria marking his first appearances for Les Bleus since October 2015 and the EURO opener against Germany his first tournament outing since the quarter-final of the World Cup against the same opponents in July 2014. The 33-year-old Real Madrid striker is a veteran of the 2008 and 2012 EUROs though is still seeking his first goal at the final tournament after eight outings.

• The 2020/21 season was a productive one for most of the players in the France squad as 15 of them collected major silverware with their clubs. Giroud Kanté and Kurt Zouma were UEFA Champions League winners with Chelsea

column1: • Mbappé was Ligue 1's top scorer for the third season running with 27 goals for Paris and also found the net eight times in the UEFA Champions League. As at the 2018 World Cup he remains aged 22 the youngest player in France's squad.

• Mbappé was one of 20 players in the France squad who played UEFA Champions League football in 2020/21 with three others involved in the UEFA Europa League. The only players who missed out on European football were Everton's Digne Monaco's Wissam Ben Yedder and Lyon's Léo Dubois.
• France have the opportunity to succeed Portugal as UEFA Nations League champions later this year
